bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to A. Diaz Albertini, December 17, 1941

div1.p: Hench poses confidential questions about Hoffmann. Hench is hesitant to honor Hoffman's request for a large number of reprints of one of Hench's papers.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to A. Diaz Albertini, December 17, 1941
div1.opener:
December 17, 1941
Dr. A. D. Albertini
Director of the Finlay Institute
Habana, Cuba
My dear Doctor Albertini:
div1.p:
Today I have a letter from Professor W. H. Hoffmann, M. D.
of Cerro 1381, Habana, expressing his interest in my article on yellow
fever in the November issue of Hygeia and requesting permission to purchase
or receive one hundred to two hundred reprints of the colored picture. I
don't know whether he wants the whole article or just the picture. Dr.
Hoffman states that he has been working for twenty-five years on yellow
fever exclusively and is director of the yellow fever department of the
Finlay. On neither of my visits to Habana did I happen to meet Dr.
Hoffmann nor have I read of his name and I am writing to you asking for
a little confidential information about him.

Is it all right for us to sell or give him these reprints?
He says that he wants to distribute them to his friends in other tropical
institutions. Most assuredly we want to honor the conquerors of yellow
fever, and you will remember that in my reprint and in the painting, Dr.
Finlay was the prime figure. I am delighted to disseminate these pictures
as widely as possible to add to the glory of Dr. Finlay and Dr. Reed and
his associates but I want to be sure that the distribution of these re-
prints is properly done.

I would appreciate therefore if you would write me confi-
dentially your advice in the matter.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
